description.narrative: The expected impacts are likely to center around: Consumers: Consumption of sugar-dense beverages (both CSD and juices) is associated with the negative nutritional outcomes for the consumers. The impacts could be mitigated by exploring reformulation or shifting production towards healthier choices. Direct and indirect employment: The Project is expected to generate 130 direct jobs and expand its local distribution and storage facilities to support small shops/kiosks (traditional trade). Environment: IBS will promote recycling, hence reducing the related carbon footprint and waste. There may be scope for market impacts along this dimension in the FMCG market in Senegal.

The proposed loan of up to 9 million (the IFC Loan) to Industrie des Boissons du Sénégal (IBS or the Borrower), a still and carbonated soft drinks (CSD) processing company, is to support the Borrowers investment program and includes: (i) expanding production capacity; (ii) implementing a packaging recycling program; (iii) Green building standards and certification, and (iv) working capital requirements.
